# The <mono>gg</mono> object

.pull-left4[

<b>1</b> ggplot returns an object of the class `gg`.<br>
<b>2</b> You can assign the result of `ggplot` to an <high>object</high>.<br>
<b>3</b> Evaluating the object will show the plot.<br>
<b>4</b> You can even edit existing <high>`ggplot` objects</high>.<br>

```{r, fig.width = 8}
# Create myplot
myplot <- ggplot(data = mpg,
                 aes(x = displ,
                     y = hwy)) + 
              geom_point() + 
              theme_bw()
class(myplot)
```

]

.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5}
myplot # Evaluate myplot
```

]

<b>1</b> ggplot returns an object of the class `gg`.<br>
<b>2</b> You can assign the result of `ggplot` to an <high>object</high>.<br>


]

# `facet_wrap()`

.pull-left45[

Faceting = <high>same plot for different groups</high>.

To facet plots, use, e.g., `facet_wrap()`.

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = TRUE, eval = F}
# Without faceting
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                     y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point() + theme_bw()
```

]

.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = FALSE}
# Without faceting
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                     y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point() + theme_bw()
```

]

---

# `facet_wrap()`

.pull-left4[

Faceting = <high>same plot for different groups</high>.

To facet plots, use, e.g., `facet_wrap()`.

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
# With faceting
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                     y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point() + theme_bw() +
  facet_wrap(~ class)  # Tilde first
```


]

.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = FALSE}
# With faceting
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                     y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point() + theme_bw() +
  facet_wrap(~ class)  # Tilde first!
```

]

---

# `facet_grid()`

.pull-left4[

Faceting = <high>same plot for different groups</high>.

Use `facet_grid()` to create plots of one (set of) variable against those another.

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = TRUE, eval = FALSE}
# With faceting
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                     y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point() + theme_bw() +
  facet_grid(drv ~ class) 
```


]

.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = FALSE}
# With faceting
ggplot(data = mpg, 
       mapping = aes(x = displ, 
                     y = hwy)) + 
  geom_point() + theme_bw() +
  facet_grid(drv ~ class) 
```

]

# `theme()`

.pull-left45[

To <high>customize the appearance of your plot use `theme()`.

`theme()` has <high>87 arguments</high> allowing to fine-tune, e.g., the background, the axes, the legend, etc. 

Arguments are specified via `element_*()` helper functions, mostly `element_rect()` or `element_line()`.

```{r, eval = F}
# use theme to change appearance
myplot + 
  theme(argument = element_*(), 
        argument = element_*(),
        etc.)

```

]


.pull-right45[

<p align="center">
<img src="image/theme.png">
</p>
]

---

# Background color: `theme()`

.pull-left45[

Address the <high>panel background</high> using `panel.background` and that of the <high>plot background</high> using `plot.background` and change the color using `element_rect(fill = color)`.

```{r, eval = F}
# change panel and plot color
myplot + 
  theme(
    panel.background = 
      element_rect(fill = 'tomato'), 
    plot.background = 
      element_rect(fill = 'burlywood'))

```

]


.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = FALSE}
# change panel and plot color
myplot = myplot + 
  theme(
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = 'tomato'), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = 'burlywood'))
myplot
```

]

---

# Background grid: `theme()`

.pull-left45[

Address the <high>grid line colors</high> using `panel.grid.major` (large grid lines) and `panel.grid.minor` (small grid lines) and change the color using `element_line(colour = color)`.

```{r, eval = F}
# change grid line color
myplot + 
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = 
      element_line(colour = "salmon"),
    panel.grid.minor = 
      element_line(colour = "seagreen")
    )

```

]


.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = FALSE}
# change grid line color
myplot = myplot + 
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = 
      element_line(colour = "salmon"),
    panel.grid.minor = 
      element_line(colour = "seagreen")
    )
myplot
```

]

---

# Background grid: `theme()`

.pull-left45[

Change the <high>grid line sizes</high> using `element_line(size = number)`.

```{r, eval = F}
# change grid line color
myplot + 
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = 
      element_line(colour = "salmon",
                   size = 3),
    panel.grid.minor = 
      element_line(colour = "seagreen",
                   size = 1.5)
    )

```

]


.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = FALSE}
# change grid line color
myplot = myplot + 
  theme(
    panel.grid.major = 
      element_line(colour = "salmon",
                   size = 3),
    panel.grid.minor = 
      element_line(colour = "seagreen",
                   size = 1.5)
    )
myplot
```

]

---

# Axes: `theme()`

.pull-left45[

Change the <high>axes</high> using the ` axis.line.x` and ` axis.line.y` arguments and `element_line(colour, size, lineend, ...)`.

```{r, eval = F}
# change grid line color
myplot + 
  theme(
    axis.line.x = 
      element_line(colour = "deeppink", 
                   size = 3.5, 
                   lineend = "butt"),
    axis.line.y = 
      element_line(colour = "deeppink", 
                   size = 3.5)
    )

```

]


.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = FALSE}
# change grid line color
myplot = myplot + 
  theme(
    axis.line.x = 
      element_line(colour = "deeppink", 
                   size = 3.5, 
                   lineend = "butt"),
    axis.line.y = 
      element_line(colour = "deeppink", 
                   size = 3.5)
    )
myplot
```

]

---

# Axes: `theme()`

.pull-left45[

Change the <high>axes labels</high> using the ` axis.title.x` and ` axis.title.y` arguments and `element_text(colour, size, lineend, ...)`.

```{r, eval = F}
# change grid line color
myplot + 
  theme(
    axis.title.x = 
      element_text(family = "Comic Sans MS", 
                   size = 3.5),
    axis.title.y = 
      element_text(family = "Comic Sans MS", 
                   size = 3.5)
    )

```

]


.pull-right45[

```{r, fig.width = 7, fig.height = 5.5, echo = FALSE}
# change grid line color
myplot = myplot + 
  theme(
    axis.line.x = 
      element_line(colour = "deeppink", 
                   size = 3.5, 
                   lineend = "butt"),
    axis.line.y = 
      element_line(colour = "deeppink", 
                   size = 3.5)
    )
myplot
```

]

# `ggsave()`

.pull-left5[

To <high>save plots</high> to a file (e.g., `.jpg`, `.pdf`, `.png`), use the `ggsave()` function.

`ggsave()` main arguments are...

|Argument| Definition|
|:-------|:----------|
|`filename`|File name|
|`plot`|Plotting object|
|`device`|File type (e.g.; "pdf", "jpeg", "png")|
|`path`|File path to save plot|
|`width`|Plot width (inches)|
|`height`|Plot height (inches)|

]


.pull-right45[

Save ggplot object called myplot to a pdf file...<br>
```{r, eval = FALSE}
# Create myplot object
myplot <- ggplot(...)

# Create "myplot.pdf", from myplot
ggsave(filename = "myplot.pdf",
       plot = myplot,
       device = "pdf",
       path = "figures",
       width = 6, 
       height = 4)
```



]
